topic_knowledge_points: A vector (array list) supports random access by index with at, set, insert, erase, size, and empty, where indices range from 0 to size()-1.
A simple array-based vector stores element i at A[i], with at and set in O(1) time and insert/erase in O(n) due to shifting.
Extendable arrays grow capacity by allocating a larger array, copying elements, and swapping pointers, enabling amortized O(1) push-back.
Doubling-capacity extendable arrays achieve O(n) total time for n push operations via amortized analysis.
STL vectors provide dynamic resizing, bounds-checked at(i), push_back/pop_back, and iterator-based algorithms and constructors.
A list ADT uses iterators as abstract positions supporting begin, end, insertFront/Back, insert(p,e), eraseFront/Back, erase(p), size, and empty.
Iterators generalize positions with element access via *p and navigation via ++ and --, with begin at the first element and end just past the last.
A doubly linked list with header and trailer sentinels implements the list ADT with O(1) insertions and deletions at known positions.
The NodeList design nests Node and Iterator classes, providing constant-time iterator increment, decrement, dereference, and comparisons.
STL list implements a doubly linked list with push_front/back, pop_front/back, front, back, size, empty, and iterator traversal.
STL containers (vector, deque, list, stack, queue, priority_queue, set/multiset, map/multimap) expose uniform iterator interfaces.
Iterator ranges use the half-open interval [p,q) and support algorithms like sort, random_shuffle, reverse, find, min_element, max_element, and for_each.
Const iterators provide read-only traversal of containers passed by const reference, ensuring elements cannot be modified.
A sequence ADT unifies list and vector operations and provides bridging functions atIndex(i) and indexOf(p) between indices and positions.
A doubly linked list implementation of a sequence gives O(1) positional updates but O(n) atIndex/indexOf via link hopping.
An array-based sequence using position objects in cells supports O(1) atIndex/indexOf and O(n) insert/erase due to shifting.
Using a circular array improves insertFront/insertBack to O(1) while general insert/erase remain O(n), with O(N) space for capacity N.
Linked-list sequences use O(n) space and constant-time positional operations, while array sequences trade space for faster index-based access.

knowledge_points.topic: Case Study: Bubble-Sort on a Sequence
topic_knowledge_points: Bubble-sort performs n passes swapping adjacent out-of-order elements so the i-th pass fixes the i largest elements at the end.
Bubble-sort runs in O(n^2) time when accesses and swaps are O(1), but using atIndex on linked-list sequences leads to O(n^3) time.

reinforcement.exercise_content: Give a C++ code fragment for reversing an array.
Give a C++ code fragment for randomly permuting an array.
Give a C++ code fragment for circularly rotating an array by distance d.
Draw a representation of an initially empty vector A after performing the sequence: insert(0,4), insert(0,3), insert(0,2), insert(2,1), insert(1,5), insert(1,6), insert(3,7), insert(0,8).
Give an adapter class to support the Stack interface using the functions of the vector ADT.
Provide the missing housekeeping functions (copy constructor, assignment operator, and destructor) for the class ArrayVector of Code Fragment 6.2.
Provide a fully generic version of the class ArrayVector of Code Fragment 6.2 using a templated class.
Give a templated C++ function sum(v) that returns the sum of elements in an STL vector v using an STL iterator.
Rewrite the justification of Proposition 6.2 assuming the cost of growing the array from size k to 2k is 3k cyber-dollars and determine the charge per push.
Draw pictures illustrating each of the major steps in insert(p,e), insertFront(e), and insertBack(e) of Code Fragment 6.5.
Provide a fully generic version of the class NodeList of Code Fragment 6.9 using a templated class.
Provide the missing housekeeping functions (copy constructor, assignment operator, and destructor) for the class NodeList in Code Fragment 6.9.
Provide a definition for a postincrement operator for the iterator in Code Fragment 6.7.
Present a more efficient atRank(i) (atIndex) for NodeSequence that walks from the closer end of the list.
Provide the details of an array implementation of the list ADT.
Given kn total accesses to a list L of n elements, find the minimum and maximum number of elements accessed fewer than k times.
Give pseudo-code for implementing all operations in the sequence ADT using an array in a circular fashion and state running times.
Using the Sequence interface, describe a recursive function to determine if a sequence S of n integers contains k, without loops, and analyze extra space.
Describe how to perform makeFirst(p) in O(1) time for a doubly linked list implementation of a sequence.
Describe how to implement an iterator for ArrayVector (Code Fragment 6.2) based on an integer index, including *, ==, ++, and --.

creativity.exercise_content: Describe changes to the extendable array implementation in Code Fragment 6.2 to avoid unexpected termination via exceptions and specify when to throw them.
Give complete C++ code for ShrinkingVector extending ArrayVector with shrinkToFit to make capacity equal to current size.
Describe changes to shrink the array size by half when the number of elements goes below N/4 in the extendable array implementation.
Show that with the grow-and-shrink strategy the series of n pushes then n pops takes O(n) time.
Describe a function to perform a perfect card shuffle of an array of 2n elements by converting into two lists and interleaving.
Improve insert(i,e) in Code Fragment 6.5 so that on overflow elements are copied directly to final places in the new array.
Analyze push operations when capacity increases by ⌈N/4⌉ instead of doubling and show total O(n) time for n pushes.
Modify NodeList to disallow using a position from one list with another list efficiently.
Realize insertBack and insertFront using only empty and insert combinations.
For Sequence<int> seq; for (int i=0;i<n;i++) seq.insertAtRank(i/2,i): (a) show the sequence after each iteration for n=10, (b) draw the final schematic for general n.
Implement indexOfElement(e) and positionOfElement(e) in terms of Sequence interface functions.
Describe an array-based vector that achieves O(1) insert/remove at index 0 and at end, and constant-time elemAtRank.
Design an efficient algorithm to uniformly randomize a vector of n cards using randomInteger(n) and give its running time.
Design a circular node list ADT that abstracts a circularly linked list like NodeList abstracts a doubly linked list.
Describe and analyze performing vector ADT operations on a sparse array represented by a list of (i,e) pairs for non-null entries.
Show that only n−1 passes are needed for bubble-sort on a sequence of n elements.
Give pseudo-code for bubble-sort using only two stacks and at most five extra variables so popping yields sorted order.
Describe and analyze an efficient algorithm to compute the natural join of list A of n pairs and list B of m pairs producing triples (x,y,z).
Describe an efficient scheme for assembling n numbered packets in order as they arrive out of order and give the running time.
Given a list L of n positive integers each with k=⌈log n⌉+1 bits, design an O(n)-time function to find a k-bit integer not in L.
Argue why any solution to the previous problem must run in Ω(n) time.
Given a list L of n arbitrary integers, design an O(n)-time function to find an integer that cannot be formed as the sum of two integers in L.

projects.exercise_content: Implement the vector ADT by an extendable array in a circular fashion so insertions and deletions at both ends run in constant time.
Implement the vector ADT using a doubly linked list and experimentally show it is worse than the array-based approach.
Write a simple text editor using the list ADT and a cursor supporting left, right, delete, and insert c, redisplaying after each operation.
Implement the sequence ADT by an extendable array in a circular fashion so insertions and deletions at both ends run in constant time.
Implement the sequence ADT by means of a singly linked list.
Write a complete adapter class that implements the sequence ADT using an STL vector object.
